programme.title: The Rise of Rome
programme.desc: How did Rome become so powerful?

programme.title: The Rise of Rome
programme.desc: The rise of Rome begins with a monarchy.

programme.title: The Rise of Rome
programme.desc: Tales and literature from early Rome give us only partial insight into factual history.

programme.title: The Rise of Rome
programme.sub-title: The Early Republic and Rural Life
programme.desc: Witness the transition from the monarchy to the republic.

programme.title: Great Ancient Civilizations of Asia Minor
programme.desc: The lands around the central Turkish plateau "face" two ways.

programme.title: Great Ancient Civilizations of Asia Minor
programme.desc: Neolithic Anatolians were among the first farmers and herders.

programme.title: Great Ancient Civilizations of Asia Minor
programme.desc: The Hittites founded a dynasty that rivaled the Egypt of Ramses II.

programme.title: Great Ancient Civilizations of Asia Minor
programme.desc: Hittite kings became the first of many conquerors to mark the land.

programme.title: Cities of the Ancient World
programme.desc: Consider why wandering ancient humans left the forests and plains to create settlements.

programme.title: Cities of the Ancient World
programme.sub-title: Catalhoyuk - First Experiment in Urban Living
programme.desc: Built in layers on a small mound, the world's first city offers a window into the Neolithic era.

programme.title: Cities of the Ancient World
programme.desc: Look past the biblical story and find out what architectural remains suggest about Jericho.

programme.title: Cities of the Ancient World
programme.desc: Located in the heart of Mesopotamia, Uruk exhibits many hallmarks of ancient civilization.

programme.title: Ancient Mesopotamia: Life in the Cradle of Civilization
programme.desc: Understand how we uncover ancient historical knowledge, and why Mesopotamia's "rediscovery" is so valuable.

programme.title: Ancient Mesopotamia: Life in the Cradle of Civilization
programme.desc: Discover the surprising theories about the transition from a hunter-gatherer lifestyle to agriculture.

programme.title: Ancient Mesopotamia: Life in the Cradle of Civilization
programme.desc: In this episode, plunge into everyday life in Neolithic Mesopotamia.

programme.title: Ancient Mesopotamia: Life in the Cradle of Civilization
programme.sub-title: Eridu and Other Towns in the Ubaid Period
programme.desc: See how the people of the Ubaid developed irrigation systems, despite a lack of written language.

programme.title: Great Board Games of the Ancient World
programme.sub-title: Bearing Off: The Story of Backgammon
programme.desc: Learn how to play this ancient game and discover why a 20th-century innovation has made all the difference.

programme.title: Great Board Games of the Ancient World
programme.sub-title: Senet: Egypt’s Game of the Afterlife
programme.desc: Learn how to play this ancient game and discover why a 20th-century innovation has made all the difference.

programme.title: Great Board Games of the Ancient World
programme.sub-title: Chess: The Evolution of a Strategy Icon
programme.desc: Discover how this ancient game of strategy wound its way westward.

programme.title: Great Board Games of the Ancient World
programme.sub-title: Chess’s Eastern Cousins: Shogi and Xiangqi
programme.desc: Explore a Chinese game called xiangqi, and a Japanese game called shogi. ?

programme.title: Decoding the Secrets of Egyptian Hieroglyphs
programme.desc: In this episode, understand why ancient Egypt had to invent some form of writing.

programme.title: Decoding the Secrets of Egyptian Hieroglyphs
programme.desc: Professor Brier shows you how to write each hieroglyph and how to position them.

programme.title: Decoding the Secrets of Egyptian Hieroglyphs
programme.desc: How is it possible for a language used by the world's greatest civilization to become lost?

programme.title: Decoding the Secrets of Egyptian Hieroglyphs
programme.desc: Explore how hieroglyphs, and the ability to read them, was rediscovered during Napoleon's invasion of Egypt.
